description.narrative: The current security context in the Lake Chad Basin linked to the Boko Haram conflict continues to drive an escalating humanitariancrisis in Diffa region in Niger (FewsNet and Cadre Harmonisé currently have the region of Diffa in IPC phase 3 (crisis) including with humanitarian assistance, until at least January 2017). As of September 2016, the region of Diffa hosts 302,387 IDPs, refugees and returnees alone.1 According to authorities from the Diffa Region, even though more than 80 per cent of the population of Bosso, who became displaced after the 3 June attacks, has returned home; commercial activities remain largely paralyzed due to continued insecurity affecting the Lake Chad Basin area and the ongoing #Emergency State# in the region. People are in desperate need for criticalitems and basic food assistance. As the crisis worsens, Diffa is facing an influx of refugees fleeing either the conflict in the surrounding countries or the increasing food insecurity. The IDP population is showing little sign of returning despite the efforts of the government and the Niger Military#s need to create a population free area between the N1 and the Nigerian border has further increased the number of IDPs. In early 2016 the IDP/refugee/returnee populationwas estimated at 93,343 refugees, 72,549 returnees and 58,000 IDPs. Following the Boko Haram attacks and occupation of Bosso in June 2016, the number of IDPs, returnees and refugees was then increased to 280,000 people. Much of the displaced populationis living in makeshift and unofficial spontaneous camps, often nextto N1 route and living with or in most cases around the host communities (Diffa#s population is 310,000 people - 2012 census) resulting in high levels of vulnerability for both IDP andhost communities and leading to further scarcity of already rare resources. Food Security needs are acute, affecting both the IDP/refugee populations as well as the host communities. Current estimates by OCHA are that only 65% of people in need of foodassistance in the Diffa region are currently receiving support, with a total 454,000 peoplein need of food assistance2. This is also leading to a worsening malnutrition crisis with Global acute malnutrition (GAM) rates exceeding the 15 per cent emergency threshold at 17.1% in the Diffa region (OCHA 06/04/2016)3. Access to food due to lack of stocks, production, income, and employment opportunities is a critical issue for IDPs and refugees as the vast majority depend on food assistance. Oxfam assessments carried out in October and November 2016 reveal people engaging in disturbing irreversible coping mechanisms in order to make money to purchase food in markets such as selling jewellery and productive assets, marrying their girls at a young age, and borrowing money to buy food and critical items. Reports of women engaging in emergency sex to access money are also widespread. The lack of livelihoods opportunities in the chronically poor Diffa region is critical; host communities and pre-existingdisplaced populations already faced high levels of food insecurity and lacked livelihoods. The burden of new arrivals is aggravating this situation (OCHA 07/06/2016). Access to food assistance is key for households to increase their dietary diversity, reduce irreversible negative coping strategies (such as the sale of productive assets), and reduce prevalence of severe acute malnutrition. Through this proposed project, Oxfam is looking at providing this essential food assistance to 500 vulnerable households in settlements alongthe N1 route, in Diffa region.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam Novib is one of the 17 national affiliates of the Oxfam International Confederation. It started life in 1956 as the Netherlands Organisation for International Assistance (Novib), and joined forces with Oxfam in 1994. Working together in confederation, the Oxfam affiliates can speak with one clear and compelling voice on issues of global concern: climate change, health and education for all, agriculture, trade, and conflicts and emergencies. Oxfam Novibs main office is based in The Netherlands, it supports the work of a network of local offices, the implementation of global projects, fund raising, campaigning and advocacy. The Hub Niamey Niger exists since 2006 as a humanitarian field office and since 2012 as the decentralized Country office for Oxfam Novib, dealing with all the development and humanitarian themes like Sustainable livelihoods, Right to Basic services, Humanitarian and resilience interventions, The right to be heard and the right to an Identity, including women's rights and sexual and reproductive health rights. The Country Office in Niger works with local partners to realize the vision of a Niger without poverty

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands
